Challenge¶

Interfaces with the Challenge model.

cccenter.python.challenge.challenge_list()¶

Returns a list of the challenges in the database.

Returns:All challenge objects in the database
Return type:[models.Challenge]

Note

Actually returns a queryset containing all challenges but can be treated as an arry.

cccenter.python.challenge.create_challenge(plaintext, ciphertext, ciphertype, key, challenge_type, users=None, dt_created=None, solved=False, dt_solved=None, solved_by=None)¶

Creates a challenge object and puts it in the database.

Parameters:
  • plaintext (str) – The associated plaintext
  • ciphertext – The associate ciphertext
  • ciphertype (str) – The cipher the challenge uses
  • key (str) – The cipher’s key
  • challenge_type (str) – The type of challenge (single, collaborative, competitive)
  • users ([models.User]) – (optional) Users registered in the challenge
  • dt_created (datetime) – (optional) The date and time the challenge was created
  • solved (boolean) – (optional) Indicates if the challenge has been solved yet
  • dt_solved (datetime) – (optional) The date and time the challenge was first solved
  • solved_by ([models.User]) – (optional) Users who have already solved the challenge
Returns:

‘ciphertext’ (str): The ciphertext associated with the challenge
Returns:

‘challenge_id’ (int): The challenge’s id
Return type:

dict

Note

The key is a string and is only recorded for future reference. The plaintext and ciphertext are used to print the challenge and check proposed solutions.

Note

If dt_created is left unassigned, the current date and time are used. This is the best default option.

Warning

Although ciphertype and challenge_type are strings, they are used to pull the correct Cipher object and challenge_type from the database and therefore must match a database entry exactly.

cccenter.python.challenge.get_challenge_info(challenge_id)¶

Returns information about the Challenge to display on the challenge page.

Parameters:challenge_id (int) – The challenge’s associated object’s id number
Returns:‘datetime_created’ (datetime): The date and time the challenge was created
Returns:‘datetime_solved’ (datetime): The date and time the challenge was first solved
Returns:‘challenge_type’ (str): The type of challenge (single, competitive, or collaborative)
Returns:‘solved_by’ ([models.User]): Who has solved the challenge
Returns:‘users’ ([models.User]): Who is registered in the challenge
Return type:dict

Note

the ‘solved_by’ and ‘user’ indices of the returned dictionary are actually query sets, but can be treated as lists.

cccenter.python.challenge.get_ciphertext(challenge_id)¶

Returns the ciphertext associated with the given challenge.

Parameters:challenge_id (int) – The challenge’s associated object’s id number
Returns:The ciphertext associated with the challenge
Return type:str
cccenter.python.challenge.get_difficulty(challenge_id)¶

Returns the difficulty of the given challenge. If multiple ciphers have been applied, returns the hardest one.

Parameters:challenge_id (int) – The challenge’s associated object’s id number
Returns:The difficulty of the challenge
Return type:str

Note

Return values can include ‘beginner’, ‘intermediate’, and ‘advanced’.

Note

Although this function supports multiple ciphers being applied to a single challenge, the rest of the code, including the models, does not.

cccenter.python.challenge.join_challenge(challenge_id, user_id)¶

Adds the given user to the given challenge.

Parameters:
  • challenge_id (int) – The challenge’s associated object’s id number
  • user_id (int) – The user’s (user object’s) id number
Returns:

Returns True if the user is added successfully. Returns False otherwise.
Return type:

boolean

Note

Practically, this function will only return False when the challenge type is ‘single’, since users are note allowed to be added to a private challenge.

cccenter.python.challenge.user_in_challenge(challenge_id, user)¶

Determines if the user is registered in the challenge and if the user already solved the challenge.

Parameters:
  • challenge_id (int) – The challenge’s associated object’s id number
  • user (models.User) – The current user
Returns:

(User in the challenge, User solved the challenge)
Return type:

(boolean, boolean)

Note

The user parameter can be passed in easily from a view using request.user.
